awd_titl_txt: A Sustainable Computer Modeling Curriculum for Mastery of  Core Biology Concepts and Computational Thinking by Secondary School Students
awd_abstract_narration:
As computing has become integral to the practice of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), the STEM+Computing program seeks to address emerging challenges in computational STEM areas through the applied integration of computational thinking and computing activities within STEM teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school (preK-12).  This project will engage high school biology teachers in developing and testing a novel approach to integrating computational thinking with the disciplinary content of a high school biology curriculum. The project will create a sequence of curriculum modules that teach students computer modeling skills using an intuitive visual programming platform as they produce applications to model fundamental concepts in biology, such as trophic pyramids, enzyme activity, ecological webs, genetic ratios, and biochemical cycles. These modules will be deployed in several school districts to measure the impact of the curriculum modules on student gains in computational thinking skills, mastery in understanding of biological systems, and interests in STEM fields and computation-based careers.  The outcomes of this project will provide insights into effective strategies for encouraging students from groups underrepresented in STEM fields to succeed in STEM and computer-based education and STEM career tracks. This project will also provide opportunities for STEM teachers to learn about computer modeling of natural phenomena and how to integrate computational thinking into the subjects they teach. 

This 3-year, design-based research project will engage high school teachers in designing, deploying, and evaluating a modified, computation-infused high school biology curriculum. Teachers in seven high schools will work with the project team to iteratively develop, implement, and revise a set of curriculum modules for teaching selected components of a general biology curriculum.  The modules will employ computer modeling exercises using MIT App Inventor, an intuitive, visual programming environment that enables users to build apps for smartphones and tablets. Validated measurement instruments, classroom surveys, systematic observations, student-built applications, project team feedback, formal tests based on in-class and out-of-class learning, and performance on New York state exams will be used to gauge the effectiveness of the revised curriculum modules and to test the hypotheses guiding the project.  Quantitative analyses of learning processes and outcomes will be based on longitudinal measures of student and teacher attitude change, engagement, collaborative process, conceptual and procedural knowledge in coding and in biology, and student choices of STEM and computer course electives. Qualitative analyses will include an examination of pedagogical culture within the classrooms and content analyses of student artifacts, including in-class and homework assignments and coded audio records of collaborative activity.  The key hypotheses being tested by this project are: (1) Students will gain greater insights into the nature of real-world dynamic biological systems as they build abstract models and explore the properties of these models through visual programming in the App Inventor environment; and (2) The activity of computer modeling itself will increase student curiosity and motivation to learn more about computer science approaches to problem solving.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objectives of the project A Sustainable Computer Modeling Curriculum for Mastery of Core Biology Concepts and Computational Thinking by Secondary School Students were: 1. To work with secondary biology teachers to develop a modified Living Environment (New York State high school biology) curriculum that introduces students to computational thinking and coding as a means of creating apps that explore key concepts in biology. 2. Study the impact of this computationally enhanced curriculum on student learning in five school districts in Nassau County on Long Island, NY. We began this project with several key ideas that we were interested in testing. First, we wanted to see if it was possible to train high school science teachers in basic coding skills so that they could then train their peers and their students. We then wanted to see if engaging students in coding apps to model key concepts in biology would help them better learn and retain biological knowledge. We also wanted to find out if engaging students in coding applied to helping them learn another science would increase their interest in computational and STEM careers. For example, one of the subject areas in high school biology that students find challenging to master is how genetic information is processed in cells. This subject is fundamental to biology, involving the coding of genetic information in a sequence of nucleic acid bases in DNA, which must be transcribed into a corresponding RNA molecule and then translated into an amino acid sequence in a protein molecule. Understanding these events and modeling them on paper is tedious, but they are processes that lend themselves to be easily coded into a computer program to produce an app that can read in a sequence of DNA bases and instantly output the corresponding sequence of RNA bases and amino acids. In order for students to complete this coding exercise they need to master the underlying biological concepts. Because coding is a creative activity that results in a working product, we wondered if the process of creating the app would drive student interest in the required biological concepts (people often have trouble learning and retaining information unless they need it to accomplish a task).

            Unfortunately, the COVID pandemic disrupted our study and prematurely ended it before we could deploy our curriculum and collect data. However, we were able to gain experience to answer some of our questions and produce some outcomes that may yet be of use to computer science and biology educators. Our main product that was successfully completed prior to the pandemic shutdown is a computationally enhanced biology curriculum which can be accessed by anyone interested in exploring it via the project website at stemc.hofstra.edu. This website provides access to all of the curriculum materials developed in consultation with our biology teacher partners. These include resources for teaching computational thinking principles and guides to using the MIT App Inventor online coding platform to teach basic coding skills and app building. There are several step-by-step guides to coding projects that develop apps relevant to the Living Environment curriculum, such as an app to convert between metric units and an app to model DNA-RNA-Protein transcription and translation, as described above. There are also pre-coded apps and accompanying laboratory exercises that cover the topics of measurement, sampling, enzyme activity, homeostasis, ecological interactions, cell division, genetics, evolution, and DNA transcription and translation. Other important outcomes are lessons learned about the challenges of attempting this kind of curricular intervention in public schools, including the reluctance of teachers to risk teaching material outside of their training and subject area (in this case, coding), the difficulties of making a coding environment work properly on different school district networks with different levels of security, and in sustaining a curricular intervention over multiple years in the face of staffing changes, technology upgrades, and ultimately, a global pandemic that shut down schools and in-person learning for over a year and a half. We are currently exploring the best forum for disseminating these lessons to the other researchers who might benefit from our experiences.
